Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: HIGH CAPACITY ENERGY STORAGE ANODE MATERIAL
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the development and widespread adaptation of next generation energy storage devices. With high energy density advanced materials, these devices can store significantly higher electric power per single charge. Particularly, rechargeable batteries with significantly higher energy density will improve; the range of electric vehicles on a single charge, operating time of defense platforms (such as aerial drones, naval vessels, exoskeletons, communication devices, etc.), amount of renewable energy stored, battery life of medical devices, and the need to charge consumer electronics less often. In addition to improved performance, high energy density devices will accelerate commercialization, adaptation, and sale of new vehicles or devices that utilize them. In turn increasing investments and revenue not only for the advanced material and battery producers, but for companies involved in manufacturing and sale of electric vehicles and devices within the United Sates.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop the production of novel, pure graphene anode material by Chemical Vapor Deposition technique using readily available material resources. Currently, graphite anode-based LIBs are the most commonly used and the most reliable energy storage devices for portable electronics, electric vehicles and electric grid storage due to their stability, low cost, and safety. However, graphite's low capacity (theoretically, 372 mAh/g) prohibits the development of higher energy density batteries. The problem is that graphite's internal structure limits lithium diffusion within interlayer spaces. We propose to replace graphite as the anode material. Our material is a newly-discovered high-quality graphene network, consisting of incommensurately-stacked multilayer graphene (IMLG) assembled in three-dimensional (3D) form. It exhibits unique structural and electrical properties that enable the reversible intercalation of large amounts of lithium within interlayer spaces of multilayer graphene. IMLG anode exhibits an extremely high reversible capacity of up to 1500 mAh/g tested as an anode material in LIB cells. Within the scope of this project we plan to scale the production of this material, while maintaining high quality, and supply IMLG to industry partners for integration testing in commercial batteries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to address the challenges facing electric vehicle adaptation, unmanned aerial vehicle flight time, and other issues dependent upon rechargeable battery energy density, the project’s goal was to successfully scale up the synthesis technology of an innovative new high-capacity graphenic anode material named as Incommensurate Multilayer Graphene (IMLG).

HeXalayer transitioned the synthesis technique to larger, custom built Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) systems and developed larger amounts of high quality IMLG production.

The main challenge of the IMLG synthesis in larger scale is graphene yield from the metal catalyst template on which graphene layer deposition is performed. At the onset of the project, 0.01% of IMLG could be collected, relative to the mass of the catalyst. We were able to optimize the conditions of catalyst treatment and hydrocarbon decomposition to achieve up to 0.9-1% yield of IMLG powder.

The purity, the size and porosity of graphene sheets was studies by Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and BET techniques. The interplane and in plane structural features of molecular IMLG was characterized by Raman spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The IMLG analysis helped us to identify the optimal synthesis conditions that produces high quality IMLG in several grams per load.

High quality IMLG powders from various CVD growths were tested in Li-ion half cells, using metallic lithium as a counter electrode. HeXalayer was able to achieve homogenous growth of IMLG anode material that performs up to 1,230 mAh/g specific capacity and stable throughout long term charge-discharge cycling with retained capacity of over 93%. The specific capacity of IMLG anodes were also independently tested and verified by other research institutions.

The primary data of IMLG anodes assembled with LCO, LMNO cathodes in small pouch cells is promising for integration into large format, high energy density Li-ion pouch cells.

The ability to reproduce high quality IMLG growth conditions at a larger scale was the pre-requisite for commercialization of this technology. With that accomplished through Phase 1, HeXalayer has gained the ability to integrate this new type of high capacity anode material into Li-ion battery cells, with potentially 3 to 4 times the energy density of the existing Li-ion battery cell technologies.

Modified by: Tereza M Paronyan
